subject: Re: [junit] junit4: Exceptions in TestListener

messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of J. B. Rainsberger
> > Sent: Thursday, September 29, 2005 5:01 AM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [junit] junit4: Exceptions in TestListener
> >
> > Kent Beck wrote:
> > > David,
> > >
> > > I think that the framework should continue to work in as
> > many situations as
> > > possible. If a listener throws an exception, the framework
> > should deal with
> > > it. Contributing to Eclipse calls this the Safe Platform
> > Rule: "As the
> > > provider of an extension point, you must protect yourself against
> > > misbehavior on the part of extenders." Here is the test I
> > came up with that
> > > I think should pass (and doesn't currently):
> > >
> > > int count;
> > >
> > > class FailingListener implements TestListener {
> > > public void testRunStarted(int testCount) {
> > > count++;
> > > throw new Error();
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void testRunFinished(Runner runner) {
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void testStarted(Object test, String name) {
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void testFinished(Object test, String name) {
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void testFailure(Failure failure) {
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void testIgnored(Method method) {
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > > public static class OneTest {
> > > @Test public void nothing() {}
> > > }
> > >
> > > @Test public void failingListener() {
> > > count= 0;
> > > Runner runner= new Runner();
> > > runner.addListener(new FailingListener());
> > > runner.addListener(new FailingListener());
> > > runner.run(OneTest.class);
> > > assertEquals(2, count);
> > > }
> > >
> > >
> > > public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
> > > return new JUnit4TestAdapter(TestListenerTest.class);
> > > }
> > >
> > > I am working on an implementation. Alternatively, should
> > the count be 1?
> >
> > If you're wondering whether the new FailingListeners should
> > be counted
> > as equal, I believe not. They aren't Value Objects, so I don't think
> > they should be compared with value equality.
> >
> > If you're wondering about something else, then ignore me and
> > wait for an
> > intelligent reply.
>
> J.B.
>
> The equality of the listeners wasn't in question. I wrote the test the way I
> did so that it didn't matter what order the listeners were called (it isn't
> guaranteed), the test would prove that both listeners were called in spite
> of their exceptions. My first version of the test had one failing listener
> and a second listener that set a flag that was checked with assertTrue(),
> but that test implicitly relied on the listeners being called in the order
> they were added.

I looked at your reply, the code, your reply, what I wrote, the code,
your reply, the code... then concluded I was drunk when I replied to
you. Sorry about that.
--
